description: From Middle English tenure, from Anglo-Norman, from Old French tenure, from Vulgar Latin *tenitura, from *tenitus, from Latin tentus (from tene≈ç) + -ura.

entries.meaning: A status of possessing a thing or an office; an incumbency.
examples: All that seems thine own, / Held by the tenure of his will alone.

entries.meaning: A period of time during which something is possessed.
A status of having a permanent post with enhanced job security within an academic institution.
A right to hold land under the feudal system.

verbs.description: tenure (third-person singular simple present tenures, present participle tenuring, simple past and past participle tenured)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To grant tenure, the status of having a permanent academic position, to (someone).
